title: Overview of Diabetes Classification and Prediction Study
text:
[PROJECT LINK]


Abstract
This study employs a comprehensive diabetes dataset to develop predictive models for diabetes classification based on critical clinical variables. Through the application of advanced visualization techniques, patterns and correlations within the dataset were explored, offering valuable insights into the key factors influencing diabetes outcomes. Regression analysis was utilized to construct robust models that identify significant predictors of diabetes classification. The findings provide a deeper understanding of how clinical variables interact in the diagnostic process, offering a foundation for data-driven improvements in early detection, diagnosis, and management of diabetes.


Introduction
Diabetes is a significant global health concern, affecting millions of individuals and contributing substantially to morbidity and mortality rates worldwide. The condition is characterized by chronic hyperglycemia, resulting from impaired insulin production or action, which can lead to severe complications if not managed effectively. Consequently, early diagnosis and accurate classification of diabetes are crucial for timely intervention and personalized treatment.
In recent years, the proliferation of healthcare data has created new opportunities to harness data analytics for enhancing our understanding of diabetes. This research focuses on leveraging a rich dataset comprising clinical and demographic variables to predict diabetes classification and gain insights into the factors influencing disease outcomes. By employing visualization techniques and regression analysis, the study investigates patterns that can aid in the diagnosis of diabetes and identifies key predictors. The outcomes of this research underscore the potential of data-driven methodologies to improve diagnostic accuracy and clinical decision-making in diabetes care.


Dataset Description
The dataset used in this study contains 1,000 entries, encompassing a wide range of clinical and demographic attributes related to diabetes. Each record includes the following features:






















Feature

Type

Description













ID

Numeric

Unique identifier for each record.













No_Pation

Numeric

Patient identification number from the medical center.













Gender

Categorical

Gender of the patient (e.g., Male or Female).













AGE

Numeric

Age of the patient in years.













Urea

Numeric

Urea level in the blood, indicative of kidney function.













Cr

Numeric

Creatinine level in the blood, used to assess kidney health.













HbA1c

Numeric

Glycated hemoglobin percentage, a key indicator of long-term glucose control.













Chol

Numeric

Total cholesterol level in the blood.













TG

Numeric

Level of triglycerides in the blood, indicative of fat metabolism.













HDL

Numeric

High-density lipoprotein (“good cholesterol”) level.













LDL

Numeric

Low-density lipoprotein (“bad cholesterol”) level.













VLDL

Numeric

Very-low-density lipoprotein level, indicating fat transport.













BMI

Numeric

Body mass index, a measure of body fat based on weight and height.













CLASS

Categorical

Diabetes classification (diabetic, pre-diabetic, or non-diabetic).













The dataset provides a rich foundation for analyzing relationships between these variables and diabetes status, enabling the development of predictive models and offering insights into diabetes diagnostics and management.


Rationale for Dataset Selection
The selected dataset is highly valuable for understanding Type 2 Diabetes, the most prevalent form of the disease. It encompasses a variety of medical and demographic parameters, including HbA1c levels, lipid profiles, BMI, kidney function markers (urea and creatinine), age, and gender. These features collectively offer a holistic view of the biological and lifestyle factors contributing to diabetes and its complications.
Key Features and Their Relevance:

HbA1c: This is a primary marker of long-term blood glucose control and is central to diagnosing and managing diabetes.
Lipid Profile (Chol, HDL, LDL, VLDL, TG): The lipid profile provides crucial information about cardiovascular risk, which is a common complication in diabetic patients.
BMI: Obesity is a significant risk factor for Type 2 Diabetes, making BMI an essential feature for predictive modeling.
Kidney Function Markers (Urea, Cr): These markers are vital for assessing the risk of diabetic nephropathy, a serious complication of diabetes.
Demographic Variables (Age, Gender): Understanding the influence of age and gender on diabetes risk can help in tailoring personalized treatment plans.

By including a diverse set of features, this dataset enables a comprehensive exploration of the interplay between different variables and diabetes outcomes. The real-world nature of the data, combined with its demographic and clinical variability, provides a robust platform for building predictive models aimed at early diagnosis and prevention.


Methodology
The study employed the following steps to achieve its objectives:
Data Cleaning and Preprocessing:

Handling missing values.
Encoding categorical variables.
Normalizing numerical features to ensure comparability.

Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA):

Visualizations were used to identify patterns and correlations between variables.
Summary statistics were computed to understand the distribution of key attributes.

Model Development:

Regression analysis was conducted to identify significant predictors of diabetes classification.
Different machine learning models were explored to enhance predictive accuracy.

Model Evaluation:

The models were evaluated using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
Cross-validation techniques were applied to ensure the robustness of the models.



Conclusion
This study highlights the power of data-driven approaches in understanding and predicting diabetes outcomes. By leveraging a rich dataset with diverse clinical and demographic variables, significant predictors of diabetes classification were identified. The insights gained from this analysis can contribute to improved diagnostic precision and more effective management strategies for diabetes.
Furthermore, the study underscores the potential of using real-world healthcare data to develop predictive models that aid in early diagnosis, personalized treatment, and preventive care. Future research could focus on expanding the dataset and incorporating additional variables to enhance the predictive capabilities of the models.

title: About
text:
Myself Ajith Raju Aumbati. I am a data-driven professional with 2 years of experience as an Application Development Associate at Accenture. Currently, I am pursuing a master’s degree in Data Analytics Engineering at George Mason University, where I am honing my skills in machine learning, statistical analysis, and predictive analytics.
As an experienced professional, I specialize in leveraging data to uncover actionable insights, build scalable solutions, and drive business value. My technical expertise spans Python, R, and SQL, complemented by proficiency in visualization tools like Power BI and Tableau. I have hands-on experience in advanced frameworks such as Scikit-learn, Numpy, Pandas, and Seaborn, which I have used to develop predictive models, automate workflows, and perform complex data analyses.
My areas of interest include Sales Analysis, where I focus on analyzing sales performance, trends, and revenue generation, and Marketing Analytics, where I measure campaign effectiveness, perform customer segmentation, and evaluate ROI. These interests allow me to combine technical expertise with business strategy to deliver impactful insights.

title: Movie Rating Predictor System Using KNN and Collaborative Filtering
text:
[PROJECT LINK]
Project Description:
This project focuses on developing a movie recommendation system using two popular machine learning techniques: k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and Collaborative Filtering (CF). The MovieLens dataset, containing 100,000 ratings for approximately 9,000 movies, was used as the basis for building and evaluating the models. The primary objective was to accurately predict user ratings for movies by analyzing historical data and user preferences.
Objective:
To build a robust recommender system that can predict movie ratings by leveraging user-item interaction data and evaluating the performance of two distinct algorithms.
Techniques Used:

k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

Supervised learning algorithm widely used in classification and regression tasks.
Non-parametric, meaning it makes no assumptions about the data distribution.
Various values of k (e.g., k=3, 5, 10) and prediction methods (weighted vs. unweighted average) were explored.

Collaborative Filtering (CF)

One of the core methods in recommender systems, focused on learning user-item interaction patterns.
CF was applied using different training/testing splits to assess its performance.
The method demonstrated high accuracy, especially when sufficient training data was available.


Dataset:
The MovieLens dataset, containing 100,000 user ratings for 9,000 movies, was utilized. The dataset presented a challenge due to sparsity, where many users had only rated a limited number of movies.
Evaluation Metrics:

Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE): Used to measure the accuracy of the predicted ratings.
Runtime: Wall-clock time was recorded to compare the computational efficiency of both methods.

Key Findings:

k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

Higher values of k generally resulted in better accuracy (lower RMSE) and slightly improved runtime.
Optimal configuration: k = 10 with an unweighted average prediction, achieving an RMSE of 1.04.

Collaborative Filtering (CF)

Achieved better accuracy than KNN, with the lowest RMSE of 0.9879 using a 90%-10% training/testing split.
Performance decreased with smaller training sets, emphasizing the need for sufficient data.


Comparison of Methods:

Accuracy: CF outperformed KNN, achieving the lowest RMSE.
Runtime: CF had a shorter runtime compared to KNN for larger values of k, making it more efficient for large datasets.

Conclusion: This project successfully demonstrated the development of a movie recommendation system using two distinct algorithms: k-Nearest Neighbors and Collaborative Filtering. While both methods performed well, CF proved to be the superior method in terms of both accuracy and efficiency for the given dataset.
Key Insights:

KNN is effective for smaller datasets and local associations but struggles with larger, sparser datasets.
Collaborative Filtering excels at capturing latent patterns in user-item interactions but requires a large amount of data for optimal performance.

Future Work:

Implementing hybrid models combining CF and content-based filtering.
Exploring deep learning-based recommender systems, such as matrix factorization and neural collaborative filtering.
Optimizing runtime further by parallelizing computations and leveraging GPU-based processing.

title: SQL-Sales-Marketing
text:
Overview
This project focuses on analyzing sales performance, customer behavior, and web event conversions using SQL. The dataset includes company accounts, orders, sales representatives, regions, and web events.

title: SQL-Sales-Marketing
text:
Datasets Used
Accounts: Contains company details such as name, website, and assigned sales representative.
Orders: Tracks order transactions, including quantities, total revenue, and timestamps.
Regions: Defines geographical sales regions.
Sales Reps: Includes details of sales representatives assigned to different regions.
Web Events: Logs website interactions by accounts, including timestamps and channels.

title: SQL-Sales-Marketing
text:
Objectives
Perform sales analysis to identify top-performing regions, accounts, and sales reps.
Analyze web event conversions and customer engagement.
Identify repeat customers and trends over time.
Optimize database queries for performance.

title: SQL-Sales-Marketing
text:
SQL Queries Included
1. General Analysis
Total accounts by region
Sales rep with the most accounts
2. Sales Performance
Revenue by region and sales rep
Average order value per account
Highest-selling product categories
3. Web Events and Conversions
Total web events per account
Conversion rates from web events to orders
Most effective marketing channels
4. Trends Over Time
Monthly sales trends by region
Seasonal patterns in orders
Average order value changes over time
5. Customer Insights
High-value vs low-value accounts
Percentage of repeat customers
Accounts with increasing/decreasing order values

title: SQL-Sales-Marketing
text:
Future Enhancements
Implement machine learning models for sales prediction.
Integrate real-time data pipelines.
Automate performance reporting dashboards.

title: Healthcare_Report
section: 📊 Power BI Claims Analysis Dashboard – Project Summary
text:
📊 Power BI Claims Analysis Dashboard – Project Summary
This Power BI project provides a comprehensive analysis of healthcare claims filed between April to June 2024. The dashboard presents patterns and trends in claims activity by gender, provider specialty, geography, claim status, and age group, offering actionable insights for stakeholders and policy designers.

🔍 Key Metrics

Total Claims: 18.74K
Average Claim Amount: ₹25.08K
Total Providers: 5,000



📅 Monthly Claim Trends

April 2024: Lowest number of claims.
May 2024: Sharp spike in claims activity.
June 2024: Noticeable drop-off in total claims.



👤 Gender-Based Insights

Total Claims by Gender:

Female: 9K
Male: 8.97K
Other: 0.77K

Trend Over Months:

Female: 3022 → 3066 → 2896
Male: 2955 → 3014 → 2998
Other: 236 → 260 → 278




🩺 Speciality-Based Observations

Most Active Specialties: General Practitioners and Oncologists
Least Claims: Cardiologists
Claim Amounts: Relatively stable across all specialties



📌 Claim Status Overview

✅ Approved Claims: 13.11K

Gender Breakdown:

Female: 6.25K
Male: 6.33K
Other: 0.53K

Monthly Distribution:

April – 4361, May – 4408, June – 4344




❌ Rejected Claims: 3.66K

Gender Breakdown:

Female: 1.77K
Male: 1.74K
Other: 0.15K

Monthly Distribution:

April – 1180, May – 1274, June – 1205




⏳ Pending Claims (Declining Trend)

Monthly:

April – 682, May – 658, June – 625

Gender:

Female: 972
Male: 901
Other: 92





🌍 Statewise Approval Rate Trends

Alabama: Steady increase across all months
Alaska: Continuous decrease until May, slight rise in June
Arizona & Illinois: Gradual rise, followed by a steep drop
California: Increased until May, then plateaued



❌ Rejection Analysis by Provider and Specialty

Cardiologists:

High Rejection Providers in East: 19, 44
Widespread Rejection (East, Center, West): Provider 41
Center-Focused Rejection: 771, 52
East & West Only: 61
Minimal Rejections: Providers 68, 59, 64, 83



Dermatologists:

Only East: Providers 3, 7
Only West: Provider 178
Only Center: Provider 351
Widespread: Providers 16, 29, 38
Very Low Rejections: 3, 30, 74



Additional Insights:

Age Group Impact: Individuals aged 20 to 60 have a significantly higher claim approval rate.
State-Provider Interaction: The combination of provider ID and the state they apply in significantly influences rejection rates.
Age, Provider, and Region Interact: Rejection is notably influenced by the interaction of age group, provider specialty, and geographic region.
